headline.main: Study Finds Teenage Drug Use Higher in U.S. Than in Europe

docs.abstract: Study released at WHO meeting in Stockholm finds that American teenagers are far more likely than European peers to use marijuana and other illicit drugs, but European teenagers are more likely to smoke cigarettes and drink alcohol; findings come from 1999 surveys answered anonymously by 14,000 tenth-graders in US and 95,000 in thirty European countries; co-author Dr Thor Bjarnason comments (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: American teenagers are far more likely than their European peers to use marijuana and other illicit drugs, but European teenagers are more likely to smoke cigarettes and drink alcohol, according to a study of 31 nations. The study, released yesterday at a meeting of the World Health Organization in Stockholm, compared the results of 1999 surveys answered anonymously by 14,000 10th-grade students in the United States and 95,000 10th-grade students in 30 European countries.

docs.abstract: First article in series An American Block: Life on 129th Street; focuses on revival of once ravished neighborhood; black, white and Hispanic young professionals now live on street that in 1994 was almost uniformly black and bent by poverty and violence; years have brought unprecedented economic growth, startling drop in crime and drugs, immigrant influx, city drive to redevelop housing and rise of neighborhood organizations that stress restoration; residents comment; photos (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: Burgers grilling, fruit punch staining baby faces, summer scenting the air. In a courtyard on 129th Street, the tenants are having a barbecue. The architecture is Mediterranean in feel, a plaza flanked by two buildings freshly painted peach and yellow. To the front, a gate to protect the pristine setting. To the rear, a Technicolor splash of green: a garden with gazebo.
